item.description: Books: “The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club” I recently finished reading The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club by Dorothy L. Sayers. Published in 1928, this is the fifth book featuring Sayers’ famous amateur detective Lord Peter Wimsey. Martin Edwards makes many mentions of Ayers in his history of mystery writing, The Life of Crime, which I recently enjoyed. So I thought I should at least give it a go. Read more…

item.title: Books: 'The Life of Crime' by Martin Edwards
item.description: Books: ‘The Life of Crime’ by Martin Edwards I just finished reading The Life of Crime: Detecting the History of Mysteries and their Creators by Martin Edwards. This 2022 release is a 622-page comprehensive history of mystery writing, from the eighteenth century to the present. Each chapter contains numerous footnotes, and the book includes a bibliography and two indexes at the back: an Index of Titles and an Index of Names.

item.title: Books: 'Karla's Choice'
item.description: Books: ‘Karla’s Choice’ by Nick Harkaway I just finished reading Karla’s Choice by Nick Harkaway. The cover identifies this as “A John Le Carré Novel”, though Le Carré — who passed away in 2020 — did not write it. Harkaway, an established novelist in his own right, is also the son of the late spy novelist John Le Carré. Karla’s Choice is set in the world of British agent George Smiley — the world that Le Carré created — and slots in between The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1963) and The Looking Glass War (1965).

item.title: Books: 'Broken Trust: A Spenser Novel'
item.description: Books: ‘Broken Trust: A Spenser Novel’ by Mike Lupica I recently finished reading Broken Trust by Mike Lupica, the 50th title in the Spenser series. A little background… Robert B. Parker created Boston private detective Spenser (“no first name”) in 1973 with The Godwulf Manuscript and continued through Sixkill, published posthumously in 2011. Sixkill was the 39th Spenser novel. Along the way (1985–1988), there was a Spenser: For Hire TV series starring Robert Urich.

item.title: The Incomparable Ricky Jay
item.description: The Incomparable Ricky Jay I think I first encountered Ricky Jay in David Mamet’s House of Games with Joe Mantegna and Lindsay Crouse. He would pop up now and again over the years in films and TV episodes, including the final season of Sneaky Pete, his last on-screen work. I enjoyed his crafty, cynical, world-weary con men wherever they made an appearance… Read more…

item.title: Books: 'The Wrong Hands' by Mark Billingham
item.description: Books: ‘The Wrong Hands’ by Mark Billingham I was browsing the New Releases shelves at one of my local libraries (we have library cards for three local systems) when I stumbled upon The Wrong Hands by Mark Billingham. I wasn’t familiar with this British author but he has a long-running series of books featuring an inspector Tom Thorne. The Wrong Hands is the second book in a different series featuring detective Declan Miller.

item.title: Books: 'The Why is Everything' by Michael Silver
item.description: Books: ‘The Why Is Everything: A Story of Football, Rivalry, and Revolution’ by Michael Silver I just finished reading The Why Is Everything: A Story of Football, Rivalry, and Revolution by Michael Silver. Silver is a sportswriter currently writing for The Athletic and has previously written for Sports Illustrated and the San Francisco Chronicle, among others. In The Why Is Everything, Silver documents the rise of a young generation of NFL coaches, many of whom started or developed under long-time NFL head coach Mike Shanahan.

item.title: Books: 'Safe Houses' by Dan Fesperman
item.description: Books: ‘Safe Houses’ by Dan Fesperman In another post, I mentioned that most main characters in espionage stories are either professional spies or unwitting amateurs. That article highlighted the failed professionals of Mick Herron’s Slow Horses / Slough House series, who fall somewhat in between. In Dan Fesperman’s Safe Houses, Helen Abell falls into this gap, as well, but from a different angle. Helen works on the fringe of the espionage business, managing safe houses for the CIA in 1979 Berlin.
